content: The Act is titled the "E. Clay Shaw, Jr. Missing Children's Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2013." It includes amendments to the Missing Children's Assistance Act, such as recognizing that many missing children are runaways and adjusting the duties and functions of the Administrator. The E. Clay Shaw, Jr. Missing Children's Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2013 includes amendments to the Missing Children's Assistance Act, such as coordinating with the United States Interagency Council on Homelessness to ensure homeless services professionals are aware of educational resources regarding child sexual exploitation. The E. Clay Shaw, Jr. Missing Children's Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2013 includes amendments to the Missing Children's Assistance Act, such as updating language to include "State and local educational agencies" in addition to governments. The E. Clay Shaw, Jr. Missing Children's Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2013 includes amendments to the Missing Children's Assistance Act, such as providing technical assistance and training to coordinate with educational agencies in identifying missing children, assisting in coordinating with child welfare agencies for foster children missing from the welfare system, and aiding in identifying and recovering victims of child sex trafficking. The E. Clay Shaw, Jr. Missing Children's Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2013 aims to provide technical assistance and training to identify missing children, coordinate with child welfare agencies, and recover victims of child sex trafficking. Federal funds for compensation at the Center are limited to 110 percent of the maximum annual salary for a member of the Senior Executive Service, with the option to pay higher rates using non-Federal funds. The E. Clay Shaw, Jr. Missing Children's Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2013 limits compensation at the Center to salary, bonuses, severance pay, and employee benefits. Amendments include changing "periodically" to "triennially" and correcting the spelling of "kidnapings" to "kidnappings". Additionally, compliance with the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act of 1974 is required for grants under the Act. The E. Clay Shaw, Jr. Missing Children's Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2013 is amended to include schools, school leaders, teachers, State and local educational agencies, homeless shelters, and service providers. Authorization of appropriations is set at $40,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2014 to 2018. Oversight and accountability measures are enhanced in the Missing Children's Assistance Act. The E. Clay Shaw, Jr. Missing Children's Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2013 is amended to include oversight and accountability measures for grants awarded by the Department of Justice. This includes audits by the Inspector General to prevent waste, fraud, and abuse, mandatory exclusion for entities with unresolved audit findings, and repayment of grant funds for non-compliance. During a 2-year period, if an entity is barred from receiving grants, the Attorney General must deposit improperly awarded grant funds into the Treasury and seek repayment from the grant recipient. An "unresolved audit finding" refers to unauthorized or unallowable use of grant funds not resolved within 12 months. Nonprofit organizations must meet specific requirements. Nonprofit organizations awarded grants must meet specific requirements, including being described in section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code and exempt from taxation under section 501(a). The Attorney General is prohibited from awarding grants to nonprofits holding money in off-shore accounts to avoid taxes. Nonprofits awarded grants must disclose their procedures as prescribed in regulations. Nonprofit organizations awarded grants must disclose their compensation process for officers, directors, trustees, and key employees to the Attorney General, including independent review, comparability data, and deliberation substantiation. The Attorney General will make this information available for public inspection upon request. No more than $20,000 can be used for conference expenditures unless approved by the Deputy. The Deputy Attorney General must provide written authorization for conferences exceeding $20,000, including a detailed cost estimate. An annual report on conference expenses must be submitted to specific committees. The House of Representatives Committee on Education and the Workforce oversees conference expenditures. Grant recipients are prohibited from lobbying DOJ or government representatives for funding. Violations result in full grant repayment. The grant recipient must repay the grant in full and is barred from receiving another grant for at least 5 years. Lobbying for a grant application is not considered a violation.
